Description: A large phallus broken from a terracotta figure, perhaps originally placed horizontally on the thighs of a seated figure: there is a broken area underneath, and it is also broken across the shaft. The glans is prominent; the tip is damaged. Probably hand-modelled. Micaceous orange-red Nile silt with a grey-brown core and covered with a white dressing. The shaft is over-painted pink and the glans red, and there appears to be an intentional brown layer over the red, presumably a paint. Narrow black lines cross each other on the shaft.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Excavation nos H5-2856 and 5231. Donated: Egypt Exploration Fund. Excavated at Saqqara in the Main Temple Enclosure of the Sacred Animal Necropolis. Egyptian Late Period or early Ptolemaic.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3257)
